div.l: And nameliche þere was a grete college
Men clepeth þe soler halle in Cantebrigge
Ther was hir whete ⁊and eke hire malt I groıı̄unde
And on a day it happed in a stoıı̄unde
Sike lay the maunciple on a maladie
Men wenden wisly þat he scholde die
For whiche þe Mellere staal bothe mele ⁊and corn
An hundred tyme more þan biforn
For there byforn he stale but curtesly
But now he was a theef outrageously
For whiche þe wardeyn chidde ⁊and made fare
But þerof sette the Millere noght atare
He crakede bost and swore it was noght so
Thanne were there ȝonge scolers two
That dwelten in the halle of whiche I seie
Testyf thei were and lusty forto pleie
And only for here merthe ⁊and reuelrie
Vpon the wardeyn besily thei crie
To ȝeue hem leue but a litel stoıı̄unde
To goo to melle and seen here corn I groıı̄unde
And hardely thei dorste leie her nekke
¶ The mellere scholde not stele hem half a pekke
Of corn ne be sleight ne bi force hem Reue
And at the laste þe wardeyn ȝaf hem leue
Iohn̄ highte þat oon ⁊and Aleyn highte þat other
Of oo toıı̄un were þei born þat highte strother
Fer in the north I can not telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy all his gere
And on an hors þe sak he caste anoon
Forth goth Aleyn the clerk and also Iohn
With good swerd and bokeler by his side
Iohn knew the wey him neded no gide
And atte Milne the sak adoıı̄un he laith
Alayn spak first al hail Symond in faith
How fares thi faire doghter ⁊and thi wyf
Alayn welcome quod symken be my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ȝe here
By god quod Iohn symond nede has no pere
